entry.title: Process only 1 Attribution registration at a time synchronously
entry.content:
This change fixes two related issues:



1. The OS event queue was processed using mutual recursion, resulting in

stack depths of up to 2000 in the extreme case (2 calls * max queue

size of 1000), using needless stack resources. And given that most

OS registrations will occur on mobile devices with perhaps fewer

system resources, it is possible that such extreme recursion would

lead to crashes.

2. The methods being invoked recursively were not properly reentrant,

leading to DCHECK failures in the best case and undefined behavior in

the worst.



The change simultaneously makes the web event queue work the same way,

which in general is more fair to other tasks, since in the worst case

1000 web events would be processed before returning.



Bug: 331915077

Change-Id: I26c775a66f84295304624133f11e5eaeaf32d832

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5407432

Commit-Queue: Andrew Paseltiner

Reviewed-by: Nan Lin

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1280339}

entry.title: Fix crash in LoginHandlerViews without manager delegate
entry.content:
This is a follow-up to https://crrev.com/c/5355654 which in the

scenario of this bug also has destroyed the delegate already. Extends

the existing safeguard in LoginHandlerViews to check for a null

manager delegate. This crash was notably reproduced under automation

frameworks like Puppeteer, Playwright with official Chromium snapshots

but not easily encountered in manual testing (race?).



While this fix mitigates the immediate issue by preventing

DidFinishNavigation events in the absence of a necessary dialog

manager and delegate, this approach acts as a temporary solution.

The broader, long-term goal is to refine HTTP authentication flow

handling and event firing during WebContents destruction, avoiding

such crashes altogether.



See https://crrev.com/c/5355654 for more context.



Bug: 331670932

entry.title: Implement security enforcements for sandboxed frame processes.
entry.content:
With OOPSIFs, it becomes possible to tighten security checks for

processes that host sandboxed frames. Namely, sandboxed frames have an

opaque origin and cannot access storage, passwords, cookies and

various other forms of data. This CL implements this restriction with

an additional check in CanAccessMaybeOpaqueOrigin() that's specific to

sandboxed frame processes, blocking all access to an existing origin's

data coming from a sandboxed process. Two other types of access are

still permitted:



- new URLs are still allowed to commit in sandboxed frames. Ideally,

we would also enforce that this requires the URL to commit with an

opaque origin, but currently this knowledge is not plumbed from

all the callers (namely, CanCommitURL and CanCommitOriginAndUrl).

This will be fixed in subsequent CLs.



- using a particular origin as an initiator origin (for example, in

postMessage) is still allowed, as long as that origin is

opaque. This is because sandboxed frames are still allowed to

communicate with other frames and send/receive messages. Note that

there are still some workarounds [1] in place that exclude opaque

origins from performing ChildProcessSecurityPolicy security checks

in the first place, which also will be removed in future CLs.



Here is a summary of current uses of CanAccessDataForOrigin(), as well

as why these are all safe to block in sandboxed frames, which is what

this CL does:



- DOM storage, such as localStorage, sessionStorage, or web

databases. These are not allowed in opaque origins.



- Passwords. Blink already enforces that opaque origins already cannot

access passwords [2], so this is just adding a browser-side

enforcement.



- cookies (the common path does not use CanAccessOrigin() and protects

cookie access by construction, but one Android-specific media path

currently still uses CanAccessOrigin() to protect cookie

access). Cookies can't be accessed by opaque origins.



- blob URL access. Blob URLs *can* be created in sandboxed frames (and

will have an opaque origin as a result), but after a recent blob URL

refactor (see net::features::kSupportPartitionedBlobUrl), that

doesn't go through CanAccessOrigin() checks. Only the old mode

(already disabled by default) still uses CanAccessOrigin(), and

specifically skips it for opaque origins [3]. Hence, it should be

safe to just treat blob URLs the same as any other type of storage

from CPSP's perspective.



- Push messaging access. These require ServiceWorkers to run in the

corresponding origin, but ServiceWorkers are blocked for sandboxed

frames: see code [4] and spec [5].



- Plugins. Plugins can't be loaded in sandboxed frames, and there's no

directive to bypass that restriction [6].



[1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/renderer_host/render_frame_proxy_host.cc;l=549;drc=79fd5d71c46d0e6ecd842867bc1c787fae68e218



[2] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/weborigin/security_origin.h;l=240;drc=79fd5d71c46d0e6ecd842867bc1c787fae68e218



[3] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:storage/browser/blob/blob_registry_impl.cc;l=639;drc=b5b5329172a1607685db895653aa928560848ed3



[4] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/modules/service_worker/navigator_service_worker.cc;l=36;drc=a5a3f3a8599e454645674a6de1a54660c34f8faf



[5] https://www.w3.org/TR/service-workers/#control-and-use-window-client



[6] https://web.dev/articles/sandboxed-iframes.



Change-Id: I4ae23c9eef75540ac96d0cfac699272a49152cf9

Bug: 325410297

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5282423

Reviewed-by: Charlie Reis

Reviewed-by: Ayu Ishii

Commit-Queue: Alex Moshchuk

entry.title: PrivateAggregationHost: Simplify logic that drops excess contributions
entry.content:
I was concerned about potential UB in ContributeToHistogram() around

`int num_to_copy`. The expression subtracts a size_t from an int before

assigning the resulting size_t into an int. I think this was actually

safe as written because of we never keep more contributions than the

maximum, but I think it deserves a rewrite.



This CL makes the following changes:



(1) It changes the type of kMaxNumberOfContributions from int to size_t.

This complies with the Chromium C++ style guide's recommendation to

use size_t for object counts, which I believe supersedes the Google

C++ style guide's decision to use int for nearly everything. See

.



(2) It adds some local type aliases and rephrases the arithmetic in a

way that I think is easier to understand.



(3) It CHECKs the invariant that we never accept more than the maximum

number of contributions.



(4) It replaces std::vector::resize() with base::span::first().

Apparently, resize() takes O(n) time relative to the size

difference, whereas the span operation should be O(1).



(5) It fixes the call to `base::ranges::transform()`, which violated the

precondition that `op` must not modify elements in the input range.

I think this was technically fine because the contribution type

boils down to a POD struct, but let's not tempt fate.



Change-Id: I8b4f65b90c6a25d0d8c646446211879ef251a545

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5402426

Reviewed-by: Alex Turner

Commit-Queue: Dan McArdle

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1280331}

entry.title: [Reland 2] Add TabFeatures and test harness for mocking out tab-based...
entry.content:
The first two attempts to land this CL were reverted not due to any

problem with the CL itself, but because a dependent CL introduced

flakiness. The flakiness has been diagnosed as a larger issue affecting

UI tests in general, see https://crbug.com/331859922. This may take time

to resolve.

test flakiness issue.

entry.title: [Read Aloud] Remove reference to fontTemplate.render()
entry.content:
In attempting to refactor menus to use cr-lazy-render, I needed to get

rid of fontTemplate.render(), but it turns out that a lot of

our tests (even outside of tests for font menu) were dependent on

this line to render everything properly.



I think this line was essentially obscuring that we need calls to

flush() in tests to force re-rendering.



Everything renders as expected in the toolbar with and without the

Read Aloud flag in an actual build of Chrome.

entry.title: [Invokers] Reland: Add HandleInvokeInternal on HTMLDialogElement
entry.content:
(This relands

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4987322 after fixing timeout issues in

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5372478)



This adds support for the experimental `invoketarget` behavior for

HTMLDialogElement.



See explainer section here:

https://open-ui.org/components/invokers.explainer/#defaults.



This introduces new behavior for HTMLDialogElements such that:



- If an `invoketarget` points to a `` (and the parent logic

fell through):

- If the `invokeaction` is `` (empty - the auto state) try to toggle the dialog as modal.

- If the `invokeaction` is `close`, try to close the dialog

- If the `invokeaction` is `showModal`, try to show the dialog as

modal.



Bug: 1494810

entry.title: Revert "Add more information to DumpWithoutCrashing"
entry.content:
This reverts commit ee5fa93613adf032c588d6ed9d68936a15c678bf.



Reason for revert: Crash we were looking for seems to have disappeared on its own -- 124.0.6367.0 has been in dev for a while with no new reports. Removing the extra debugging info to clear up



Original change's description:

> Add more information to DumpWithoutCrashing

>

> We're seen some crashes where the stack generated by a

> DumpWithoutCrashing is corrupted. Record the location in a crash

> key so that we can debug these corrupted crashes.

>

> BUG=b:324771555

entry.title: Support redirect chains in Attribution Reporting interop tests
entry.content:
The input responses field may now contain an arbitrary number of

entries, instead of requiring exactly 1. Each such entry has an

associated timestamp: it is implicitly the registration time on the

first entry (for brevity) but must be explicitly set on all subsequent

ones. Each response across all redirect chains must have a unique

timestamp, as before.



We remove the now-irrelevant attribution_src_url field, though we may

re-introduce something similar in the future if we decide to cover

behavior related to the first URL in the request.



Bug: 330555387

entry.title: Add ancestor chain to partition key and update call sites and tests
entry.content:
This is the initial implementation of the ancestor chain bit addition to the cookie partition key.



The unit tests associated with the partition key have also been added and/or updated accommodate the new value.



For all the methods with parameters added to them, they have been given default values so that preexisting code will be able to work with them. This was done to allow for the wide spread changes to the codebase to be broken up into smaller CLs and after all those land another CL to address https://crbug.com/325439525, will be used to change the methods to require values be passed.

entry.title: Cleanup html/css for NTP Customize Chrome buttons
entry.content:
The html and css for Customize Chrome buttons was getting too messy.

Nothing should change visually with these changes, other than actually

using our non-hover background color and removed forced colors for high

contrast mode. It is mostly code cleanup.



Changes of note:

* All checks for GM3 were removed since GM3 is default on now. This

includes everything in this file, not just the buttons. However,

almost all of it was in the buttons.

* Removed the movement left part of the animation on the wallpaper

search button. I don't notice a visual difference, and it was

causing the button to not be where it is supposed to be. I'm not

sure how it was working before.

* We actually were using our hover color as our color for the buttons.

I assume that was a bug because it didn't make sense to set the

non-hover color and immediately override it with the hover color.

Ignoring whether it is currently being hovered on or not.

* Switched to using cr-icon.

* Removed the button containers. There was a comment claiming that the

containers have to be there because cr-button has a transparent

background. However, we can override the background color for a

cr-button, so that is unnecessary.

* Removed all styles related to forced-colors. cr-button has styles for

that (though I think they just turn it off). We shouldn't need to

write our own styles here.

entry.title: [CrOS VPN] Only check if there is an always-on vpn package name
entry.content:
Instead of checking whether the always-on vpn package has a true

lock-down value, check if there is a non-empty name. This is

because the lock-down value is true right when the admin activates

an always-on vpn package, but turns false shortly after. The

vpn package name is always non-empty when the admin specifies

an always-on vpn, and empty when the admin does not specify

an always-on vpn.



Bug: b/302744527

Test: browser_test, chromeos_unittest, and manual

entry.title: Update SetLocale comments.
entry.content:
BrowserProcess::SetLocale had a comment that this is only called on

startup before any threads are created, but this is not true in Ash

which calls this in response to system locale changes. (On other

platforms, changing the locale at runtime is either not possible or

requires a browser restart.) This comment is removed.



Clarify in the header that SetLocale doesn't actually update the UI. The

Ash code that sets the locale has to do a bunch of other stuff to ensure

the UI is up-to-date.



Change-Id: I2205723bb54d821ac087fdc4f30d0fec36b37ee4

entry.title: media/gpu/chromeos: Change IP storage type config
entry.content:
The ImageProcessor::PortConfig previously contained a vector of

VideoFrame::StorageType's. However, the vector was only ever configured

to be one long.



This changes the PortConfig storage_type vector to a singleton.



Doing this simplifies the ImageProcessorBackend Create() functions since

they no longer need to loop through the vector. Also the Create()

functions can pass the original input and output PortConfig arguments

to the constructor. Previously, a new PortConfig was created with the

first "acceptable" storage type.



Bug: None

Test: Chrome compiles.

Test: Decoding and encoding tests pass.

Test: image_processor_tests pass.

entry.title: [IntersectionOptimization] Use cached rects on scroll only and bug fixes
entry.content:
This may be the last effort for IntersectionOptimization.



Now IntersectionOptimizatio uses the following cached rect

invalidation method:

- If the change is not scroll and visibility only, don't use cached

rects; This avoids the complexity and under-invalidation issues

for the cached rects.

- If the change is scroll and visibility only, use the cached rects

if there are no intermediate clippers.



Bug fixes:

- No-change transform update was treated as a non-scroll-only change

(fixed in OnUpdateTransform in paint_property_tree_builder.cc);

- Scrollbar paint invalidations were treated as non-scroll-only

changes (now check for paint invalidation reason on the

DisplayItemClient instead of NeedsCheckLayoutForPaintInvalidation).



Bug: 40883761

Change-Id: Ic821c7d02420cf863d11ab1acd7a70180cf78a7f

entry.title: [Read Aloud] Ensure Read Aloud works with PDFs
entry.content:
Previously, Read Aloud checked for a starting node by checking that

the first text node id was not equal to -1. But this was an incorrect

assumption, as PDF node ids may be negative.



This CL cleans up the Read Aloud code so that we're now using null to

track whether or not a node id has been set, instead of using -1.

entry.title: Send current timezone on TimeZoneMonitorClient connection.
entry.content:
There's a timing issue. E.g.:

- zygote is set up the timezone A.

- renderer is being spawned from the zygote, so set to timezone A.

- browser process found timezone update timezone B, then notify.

- zygote may receive the update, but this is too late for the

renderer's timezone initialization.

- then, renderer connects to browser process's TimeZoneMonitor.

- So, the renderer cannot receive the timezone update.



This CL now sends the timezone always to the TimeZoneMonitorClient

so the receiver can eventually know the latest timezone.



BUG=40799826

TEST=Launch with Lacros many times. Tryjob.



Change-Id: I8f622aff3539a0c5a3080b13a8c7bfd0ce14717f

entry.title: 🧇 Add recording for search engine position on the choice screen
entry.content:
These positions are uploaded via UMA, but since the format of the data

we'd need to get useful position stats across country and search engine

does not really match a format native to Finch, we are here encoding

multiple position data point into sparse histograms, that we will

decode using bespoke logic at the metric analysis time.



See http://b/325015554#comment2 for a sample output of the histograms

and http://go/chrome-choice-screen-positions-histogram-design for more

background on the approach and requirements.



To obtain the data, this CL also includes a defensive refactor, to

explicitly obtain the list to show in the choice screens only once

per profile, and derive the histograms specifically from that data.

We can then avoid refetching a new list just for logging, that could

potentially be different in case there is a bug.



Bug: 325015554

entry.title: [FPF] Create new fingerprinting_protection_filter in components/.
entry.content:
A new component is needed because the code will be shared between Blink and the browser process.

In order to have comprehensive filtering of all resource loads we will need filtering logic both

within the browser and on renderer processes. The renderer-side filtering will also depend on

Page-level activation in and communication from the browser.



It's a different component from components/subresource_filter/ because it caters to a new

ruleset anddifferent activation conditions but the directory structure will be similar.

entry.title: Implement ApplyIncrementalSyncChanges in ProductSpecificationsSyncBridge
entry.content:
ProductSpecificationsSyncBridge receives changes from the sync server

via ApplyIncrementalSyncChanges. The local store and in-memory

representations of the specifics are updated. Where there is a

collision, the latest specifics/product specifications are used.

MergeFullSyncData is the same as ApplyIncrementalSyncChanges because

the user cannot access product specifications unless sync is turned on

(i.e. there is no local data to merge).

entry.title: Reland "[line-clamp] Refactor line-clamp related fields"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit b22d7d7db5c737282b4af79988b92eb378643f05,

which was reverted in commit cd165086869441b926b249bae95df2e381a15f84.



The original commit was reverted because it was causing performance

regressions on layout benchmarks. This regression was caused by two

factors:



1) `ConstraintSpaceBuilder::SetLineClampData` mistakenly always

allocated a new block rare data even when `LineClampData` had its

default disabled value, which meant every single call to

`BlockLayoutAlgorithm::CreateConstraintSpaceForChild` allocated and

populated `RareData` and `BlockData`. This reland checks that the

`LineClampData` value is not disabled before calling `EnsureRareData`.



2) The original patch refactored an if-condition in

`InlineLayoutAlgorithm::CreateLine` into a separate method

`ShouldLineClamp`. This condition, however, was in the middle of a hot

loop, and this new method was not being inlined. This reland therefore

marks the implementation as `ALWAYS_INLINE`.



> [line-clamp] Refactor line-clamp related fields

>

> In preparation for implementing `line-clamp` as a CSS property, this

> change moves the various line-clamp-related fields in

> `BlockLayoutAlgorithm` and `ConstraintSpace` into two separate

> structs: `LineClampData` and `BlockLineClampData`, adding utility

> methods.

>

> This patch does not change any user-facing behavior, and therefore it

> does not add any tests.

>

> Bug: 40336192

> Change-Id: Iccdeeabd4e139d4f7996bb4f59f6219d540cc7de

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5307216

> Commit-Queue: Andreu Botella

> Reviewed-by: Ian Kilpatrick

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1268596}

entry.title: capture_mode: Make the shelf un-selectable in window capture mode
entry.content:
This CL indirectly fixes an issue where window capture mode on the shelf

would produce a recording with unexpected contents. The underlying

reason was that the window recording would be performed on a descendent

of the shelf rather than the shelf window itself. This CL makes it so

that the shelf will not be selectable for recording.



Users that really want to record the shelf will still have the option to

use the region capture mode.



BUG=b:330124277

entry.title: [a11y]: swap vector of AXTreeUpdate(s) in RenderAccessibilityImpl::SendAccessibilitySerialization
entry.content:
- experimentally yields a ~2% performance improvement

- swap should be more efficient than std::move

1. AXTreeUpdate does not actually define a move assignment operator

2. move assignment operators are not automatically generated due to the

presence of both a copy constructor and destructor

3. copy elision may or may not take place

entry.title: [//gpu] ClientSI: Remove usage of GetPlatformSpecificTextureTarget()
entry.content:
This CL inlines the values returned by

GetPlatformSpecificTextureTarget() [1] inside

ComputeTextureTargetForSharedImage() on all platforms other than Mac.

This provides a step on the path toward complete decoupling of

ClientSharedImage's `texture_target_` field from the legacy functions

that compute texture targets, which will enable getting rid of those

functions entirely once the codebase is definitively transitioned to

ClientSharedImage::GetTextureTarget().



Transition of the Mac call will follow; it is slightly more complex as

we need to transition to using

SharedImageCapabilities::macos_specific_texture_target.



[1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:gpu/command_buffer/common/gpu_memory_buffer_support.cc;l=181-198?q=GetPlatformSpecificTextur&ss=chromium



Bug: 41494843

Change-Id: I4d9918d37c1ebffbb7776d8678b7d4615da16bf6

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5402490

Reviewed-by: Corentin Wallez

Commit-Queue: Colin Blundell

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1280183}

entry.title: Decouple browser test state observation from its modifier.
entry.content:
Removes issuing RPCs from the state observation, creating cleaner flow.



Speculatively decreases flakiness rate by:

* explicitly ceasing the observation of the browser state (since Reset and Define manipulate the same state but in opposite way),

* adding some space between starting browser state observation and issuing RPC that will change it,

* replacing adult page, as the current one seems to 503 often also contributing to flakiness (503 page is not the intended end-state)



Bug: 328036610

Change-Id: I3cb776c3d141891184cd59baa9b1b1eaee76b502

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5402480

Commit-Queue: Tomek Jurkiewicz

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1280182}

entry.title: Provide ToBufferFormat() access to ClientSharedImage.
entry.content:
ClientSharedImage needs to use ToBufferFormat() in order to

work with MultiPlanar SharedImage format.

One solution is to move the ToBufferFormat from service side to

client side code. But since we want to phase out BufferFormat usage

in future, we do not want all clients to access this method.



Hence allow restricted access to that method only to ClientSharedImage

via new classes implemented in this CL.



Bug: 1431344, 330743881

entry.title: [PWA] Remove OS Hooks Errors from OS integration manager
entry.content:
To further break the cleanup of the non synchronize OS integration

flow, this CL removes the OsHooksErrors struct. Most of the changes in the CL is mechanical, and involves removing instances to it and cleaning up the os_integration_manager include.



The main changes to support the new Synchronize() behavior are:

1. `RemoveWebAppJob`: Instead of relying on the errors to determine

success rate, a web app removal should wipe out the entire

os_integration_state field in the web_app DB. This CL introduces

behavior that measures the before and after state to determine if

a removal of OS states were successful.

2. To support 1, minor changes were made into

`OsIntegrationManager::WriteStateToDB()`, which would not write

the state if web_app->is_uninstalling was set to true. That condition

was removed.

3. Additionally, the `os_uninstallation_registration` field would

never be empty once set, even during uninstallation, so this CL takes

care of that by emptying that proto inside the OS integration state.



For manifest updates, the kUpdateTaskFailed is not used anymore

starting this CL, so that will be removed in a subsequent CL.



Bug: 328226797

Change-Id: Ib674e19d9817f125bb6f5b34dd1a4ad31749a865

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5373844

Commit-Queue: Dibyajyoti Pal

entry.title: Clean up AttributionCookieChecker usage
entry.content:
- Introduce callback alias

- Remove deferred callback from queue before invoking in

MockCookieChecker in order to avoid a situation in which synchronous

recursion could end up invoking the same callback twice

- Simplify callback usage in AttributionCookieCheckerImpl using Then



A follow-up change will simplify MockCookieChecker because it is

currently unrealistic: Based on how AttributionManagerImpl works, there

can never be multiple deferred callbacks, but MockCookieChecker (and

tests using it) operate under the assumption that this is possible.

entry.title: Fix check in GridSet constructor to handle CSS calc().
entry.content:
This is the result of auditing all callers of Length::IsPercent, to find

things that would cause incorrect behavior with calc() and/or

calc-size().



In the long term, this check and many others in this file should

probably handle calc-size() (since I think we *probably* should support

calc-size() for grid track sizes), but for now just fix this one check

that is inconsistent with the rest.



Without this change, the modified test fails a DCHECK() in

GridSizingTrackCollection::InitializeSets().



Bug: 313072

entry.title: graphite: Remove separate ANGLEDebugLayer feature flag
entry.content:
Currently, SkiaGraphite feature is checked in the browser process after

making an educated guess about whether it will be possible for the GPU

process to use Graphite.



On Mac, this involves checking ANGLE Metal feature state and the

hardware model name against a list to match ANGLE Metal's blocklist.

However, based on UMA data from the wild, we see cases where ANGLE

Metal is disabled, but we're still registered in the enabled group for

Graphite - this is precisely the scenario the early check was designed

to avoid.



Closer inspection of the experiment config by vasilyt@ points to

ANGLEDebugLayer feature check as a culprit. This feature is configured

in SkiaGraphite experiment groups and checked in gl_display.cc code

independently of SkiaGraphite feature state. Checking a feature can

enroll the client in experiment groups that specify that feature.

Therefore, it's possible that a client is falling into the SkiaGraphite

enabled arm only because the client checked ANGLEDebugLayer.



This CL fixes that by only enabling ANGLE's debug layer if GrContextType

is GraphiteDawn and Graphite backend validation FeatureParam is enabled,

getting rid of the separate ANGLEDebugLayer feature flag as a result. It

also removes the SkiaGraphiteDawnShareDevice FeatureParam that's never

set to a non-default value via finch and is obsolete at this point.



Bug: 331680185

Change-Id: I470846e311e89e63f793783b52ee01d46e85e17e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5403504

Reviewed-by: Colin Blundell

Commit-Queue: Colin Blundell

Auto-Submit: Sunny Sachanandani

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1280143}
